page.title: 16Interview, Aldridge resident
page.content: This is part of an interview with Mrs. Dorothy Wynne. "I came to Aldridge as a child with my family from Walsall in 1922. Our house had oil lamps which burned paraffin. The only heating in the house was by coal fires, we had no electricity, no gas and we had no taps in the house. We got our water from 2 pumps in the yard.{The Croft}had a hedge around it and gates and the farmer kept his cows on it, children going to school had to dodge them. There was a large iron gas lamp at the bottom of the High Street with a horse trough under it. Coal from{Stubbers Green,}milk and bread all came by horse and cart. There was an old stone Toll House at the corner of Walsall Rd and Birmingham Rd. The village has become a town. The thing I am most glad about is that childrens educational opportunities are better.
